results.title: On top of the world
results.creator_credit: Raymond Hall, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An inspiring portrait of Glenda Watson, a young teenager with cerebral palsy who cannot walk, but who can ride a horse. She is one of a group of physically disabled people who are improving their capabilities with the help of volunteers at the Pacific Riding for the Disabled Association. This rewarding form of recreation with therapy is a welcome change for Glenda and provides the thrill of close contact with and control of another moving creature. In fact, when she’s riding, she feels “on top of the world.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Raymond Hall, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Cyprus: A People Divided
results.brief_description: In 1974 the Turkish army invaded and occupied the northern half of the Mediterranean island of Cyprus. The Greek-Cypriots who formed 80% of the island’s population became refugees and the territories remain occupied by Turkey to this day. The video focuses on the experiences of Greek-Cypriot refugees who were forced to flee the northern zone in 1974. The second part of the video looks at the achievements of the Women’s Walk Home movement in 1986 in which thousands of Greek-Cypriot women, supported by international women’s groups, illegally crossed over into the northern zone to protest the Turkish occupation.

results.title: Cycling: still the greatest
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, Jacques Bobet, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Scenes from the 1976 Olympics and the 1978 Commonwealth Games capture all the thrills and excitement of cycling. Featured are some of the world’s best cyclists and their coaches, in training and in competition. This fast-growing sport is attracting the attention of cyclists and spectators alike.

results.title: On the waves of the Adriatic
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie and Brian McKenzie Film Productions
results.brief_description: Melbourne filmmaker Brian McKenzie spent 5 years working on this engrossing study of a not-so-typical Brunswick household. McKenzie plays a central part as he documents the lifestyle of Graham (a youth in his 20’s), his family and friends. After having spent so long with the family, McKenzie becomes part of the furniture- a situation which enables him to dig deep into the subjects’ lives.

results.title: Ivanhoe
results.creator_credit: Stuart Orme, Jeremy Gwilt, A&E Television Networks and BBC
results.brief_description: Sir Walter Scotts novel adapted by Deborah Cook is a superb epic. A story set in England in 1192 of a Saxon knight who returns from the crusades to find that life is not the same as as before he left. His beloved - the fair Rowena - is now engaged to Athelstane Prince of the Saxons, his father has disowned him therefore he has no inheritance and his honour is besmirched by false rumours about his actions in Palestine. All these trials he needs to overcome, at the same time as he attempts to save the lovely Jewess, Rebecca, from the hands of a misguided Norman knight who feels that his soul is in peril by loving her. A great adventure story of knights, quests, chivalry, courage, honour, sword- fights and a love story to boot. A superb cast headed by Steven Waddington, Ciaren Hinds, Susan Lynch, Victoria Smurfit, James Cosmo and Christopher Lee.

results.title: Ivan the Terrible: part 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sergei Eisenstein, Alma-Ata Studios and Mosfilm
results.brief_description: This film is the second part of a trilogy that was not completed. Although filmed shortly after Part One in 1946, the film was suppressed and was not released until 1958. It is also the last film Eisenstein made. In the trilogy Eisenstein planned to show the inner struggle of the first Czar of Russia and founder of the Russian state, in his effort to consolidate the unity of the realm against its enemies at home - the boyars or feudal noblemen - and neighbouring powers. Part Two takes up the story of Ivan the Terrible (Nikolai Cherkasov) upon his return to Moscow from Alexandrov. The complex story is full of intrigue, high level political in-fighting, family resentment and suspicion, and assassination plot, executions and murder in the cathedral. Two reels of the original were filmed in colour. The banquet scene towards the end of the film was Eisenstein’s first use of colour stock. In Russian with English subtitles. Cast includes Serafima Birman, Pavel Kadochnikov, Mikhail Zharov, Vsevolod Pudovkin. Original music by Sergei Prokofiev and cinematography by Andrei Moskvin, Eduard Tisse.

results.title: Ivan the Terrible: part 1 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sergei Eisenstein, Alma-Ata Studios and Mosfilm
results.brief_description: Ivan the Terrible part I is Eisenstein’s boldest and most successful experiment in stylisation drawing upon other arts - Wagnerian opera, Marinsky ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre - which he had begun in “Alexander Nevsky”. Ivan’s personal life is interwoven with the themes of his drive for empire and his alliance with the merchant class against the aristocracy. It is the first part of a trilogy; part 2 is dominated by cloak-and-dagger intrigue; part 3 which was to be in colour, was designed but not filmed. Cast includes Nikolai Cherkasov and Ludmila Tselikovskaya.

results.title: Ivan the Terrible = Ivan der Schreckliche [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Motoko Sakaguchi, Naxos Deutschland and Videoland
results.brief_description: Performance of Sergei Prokofiev’s “Ivan the Terrible” in two acts by the Ballet and Orchestra of the Bolshoi Opera Moscow at the Bolshoi Theater. Choreography by Yuri Grigorovich and featuring dancers Yuri Vladimirov, Batalya Bessmertnaya, Boris Akimov and Anastasya Akimov. Note: subtext is in Russian and credits in German.

results.title: Ivan and Abraham = Moi Ivan, toi Abraham [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Yolande Zauberman, Jean-Luc Ormieres, Rene Cleitman, Films Balenciaga, Hatchette Premiere and UGC Images
results.brief_description: This beautifully directed and photographed debut feature film by Franco-Polish filmmaker, Yoldande Zauberman, is set in a 1930s Polish shtetl, or small Jewish community, during a time of impending religious and political tensions leading up to Hitler’s invasion of Poland. It tells of a unique and special friendship between two young boys, Abraham (Roma Alexandrovitch), a nine year-old Jewish boy and Ivan (Sacha Iakovlev), a fourteen year-old Catholic boy, and their determination to remain best friends as religious prejudices begin to surface in the Polish community and within Abraham’s own family. When Abraham’s grandfather tries to stop the boys from seeing one another, they decide to runaway together. Added to this family drama is the alienation between Abraham’s teenage sister, Rachel (Marina Lipkina) and their father, who disapproves of Rachel’s relationship with Aaron (Vladimir Machkov), a young Communist activist. Aaron and Rachel also take flight to escape the prejudices and intolerances and to seek out Abraham and Ivan. The film focuses on these four young outcasts, their relationships and the drama of living in uncertain times. Filmed evocatively in black and white with quite an impressive young cast, “Ivan and Abraham” captures the essence of life between the Wars in Eastern Europe and the intolerances which existed, not only religiously, but politically and ethnically. Cast also includes Alexandre Kaliaguine, Helene Lapiower, Rolan Bykov, Zinovi Guerdt. In Yiddish, Polish, Russian and Gypsy dialect with English subtitles. (Awards: Cannes, 1993; Moscow, 1993)

results.title: Itzhak Perlman: Beethoven violin concerto in D, op. 61
results.brief_description: This video recording of Beethoven’s violin concerto in D, op. 61 was produced in the studio and features the exquisite music of Israeli born violin virtuoso, Itzhak Perlman accompanied by the Philharmonia Orchestra (leader, Carl Pini) and world-renowned conductor, Carlo Maria Giulini.
